Milner Gibson obtained leave to bring in a bill to amend the Shipping acts, and give effect to some recommendations of the late Shipping Committee.

div4.head: How Lincoln's Emancipation policy in regarded.
div4.p:
The London Times in another editorial on Mr. Lincoln's Emancipation Message, says it can hardly be looked anything more than an invitation to the subject in Congress.
It is clear that if slavery is to cease even in the Border States, the change must be accomplished by other means than those at which he points, which means, it is certain, are totally inapplicable to the whole Union.
The Times fears the proposed a topic of compromise will be difficult of access, per does it believe it will shake the revolution of the South; as a proposition however, which he possibly had, to the cessation of the frightful conflict, the Times thinks it worthy of discussion.
The President truly says the expenses of the war would buy up the slaves in any given State.
If this has any meaning, it is that the money now devoted to keeping up the armies of the North might be more advantageously devoted to the extension of slavery in those regions which are uncontested in its power.
If they are content to keep the slave States which have not seceded, and to try the plan of emancipation and compensation on them, they may, if really accomplish after a time a great work; but with the expenditure $2,000,

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 86, page 3.

div3.p: a day, and with nothing but shinplasters for money, the plan of attaching the wavering slave owners by compensation must follow the fate of so many other attempts at compromise.

The Daily News thinks the proposition fair, moderate and magnanimous.
It says the scheme affords at least a good beats for a comprehensive, proc and amicable debate.
Only the public by whom it has to be discussed, is earnestly capable of the order needed for real deliberation and decision.
The Morning Star also approves of the proposition.
The World thinks both sides will regard it as a dishonoring compromise.

The Morning post treats it as a puerile and vain scheme.
It says it can only be accounted for as being the last resource of a Government which feels it is engaged in a struggle which, if continued, must involve it in pain, and which it would make any sacrifice short of submission to arrest

The London Globs regards the proposition as a piece of political strategy in aid of Gen. McClellan, which is certainty well timed for securing the border States to the North.
It also regards the step as a of deep misgiving in the Washington Cabinet, touching the impolicy of pursuing the was beyond the limits required to establish boundaries and arrange the relations of Federal and Confederate States.

div4.head: France.
div4.p: The Corps Legisiatif finally adopted the whole address to the Emperor by a vote of 245 to 9.

The Paris Farrie, in regard to the alleged plan of arrangement in Mexico, asserts that nothing would be determined upon until the arrival of Gen. Lorences, who took out formal instructions and the programme of the French Government.
Gen. Ronay had gone to Toulon to embark for Mexico.

The Society for the Propagation of Commercial Reform in France had unanimously resolved that it was expedient to repeal all customs and duties on raw material for building and fitting out ships, and to assimilate all flags as regards customs and duties.
The Paris correspondent of the Times regards his as the most important free trade manifestation yet made in France.
The Bourse, on the 24th was firm and active at 70th 100 for Renles.

div4.head: Italy.
div4.p: The Pope is again ill very weak, and confined to his bed most or the day. All audiences are suspended.

Garibaldi has left.
Turin. A perfectly good understanding exists between him and Rattan.
It is asserted that after nine months solicitation, Omar Pasha obtained from the Porte permission to attack Meatenegro.

Dervish Pasha, with 10,000 Thiks, was moving on the Montenegrin frontiers.
The Montenegro were making great preparations.

div4.head: Latest via Queenstown.
div4.p: Milan, Sunday, March 28 --There was great enthusiasm and festivity here in honor of Garibaldi last night, at his hotel.

Allianzi, of Milan, publishes a programme of action in Hungary agreed on by Kossuth, Klapka, and Turr.
The principal points are the establishment of a constitutional Kingdom, with the exclusion of the Hapsburg, dynasty; civil equality for all the inhabitants of Hungary; and an offensive and defensive alliance between Hungary, Servia, Croatia, and Roumelia.

div4.head: Commercial.
div4.p: Trade Report. --The advices from Manchester are favorable, the markets for goods and yarns being firm and quiet.

div4.head: Liverpool Breadstuffs market.
div4.p:
The Breadstuffs market is dull.
Wheat has a downward tendency, with a slight decline on all qualities.
The various circulars report.
Flour downward, at 26s 6da29s. Wheat dull, and declined 2d per cental; red Western, 10s 6d alla 6d; red Southern, 11s 8d alla 10d, white Western, 12s 6d; white Southern, 12s 8d 12s 10d. Cora, quick and steady; mixed, 28s 9d; 29s.

div5.p: Cotton.--The sales yesterday (Saturday) amounted to 8,000 bales; the market closing steady, but dull, at unchanged quotations.
Breadstuffs.--The market is very dull, with a downward tendency

Provisions--The provision market closed quite.
Lard and Bacon were firm at previous quotations.
London--Consols, closed on Saturday at 84½ 24½ for money.

div4.head: Haver market.
div4.p:
Conca.--The sales of the week have been 3.500 bales. The market is quiet and steady Orleans.
tree ordinaire, 155 f.; bas, 147, Stock in port, 51,000 bales.

div3.head: A Singular Prophecy.
div3.p: --The following circumstance recently occurred at Pensacola, and its truth is vouched for by a reliable officer of the army;

A soldier in the Confederate service fell into a long and profound steep, from which his comrades vainly enslaved to arouse him At last he woke up himself.
He then stated that he should die the next afternoon at 4 o'clock, for it was so revealed to him in his dream — He said in the last week of the month of April would be fought the greatest and bloodiest battle of modern times, and that early in May peace would break upon the land more suddenly and unexpectedly than the war had done in the beginning.
The first part of the prophetic dream has been realized for the soldier died the next day at 4 P. M. Will the rest be in April and May?
Let believers in dreams wait and see.--Mobile Advertiser.

div3.head: Attack on Fort Pulaski.
div3.p:
By reference to our telegraphic column, it will be seen that the enemy have at last opened fire on Fort Pulaski.
It is, perhaps, generally known that communication between this fortification and the city of Savannah, for the protection of which it is designed, has been intercepted for sometime.
We think it more than probable that the Fort will be reduced and captured; but we are not of opinion that the fall of Savannah followed as an inevitable consequence.
It is not altogether improbable, however, that ally may, in the course of a few weeks, be added to the conquests of the enemy.
Even should this occur, we think there would be nothing to discourage us, or to create the impression for a moment that all is lost.
Our seaport and river towns will, many of them, doubtless fall into the hands of the enemy during the coming summer, and much inconvenience and many sacrifices result therefrom; but every town thus captured will require more or less force to hold it in subjection, by which the really available force of the enemy will be greatly weakened.
Our own force will be correspondingly strengthened by concentration, and will be made available and efficient at interior points of attack.

div3.head: The army of the Mississippi.
div3.p:
We learn that telegraphic dispatches received by the Government yesterday sustained the statements of the dispatch from Corinth published by as yesterday morning --Van-Dorn, it is understood, has joined Beauregard, and we may look for another grand battle near Corinth with no great delay.--The best authority represents that at least three thousand of the enemy are secured as prisoners, and that at large part of the ammunition, and equipments captured on Sunday have been saved from recapture in the withdrawal to Corinth.
The army is in the very best spirits, and eager for another fight with the enemy.

div3.head: The Peninsula.
div3.p:
Captain Webb, of the Teszer, came up with his vessel yesterday morning from Warwick river.
He states that an a body of the enemy were attempting to cross that river, Wednesday evening he fired a few shell amongst them.
While engaged in thus interrupting them, a shell exploded in the gun and bursted it. He was compelled to come up to replace it with another.
He will return immediately this is accomplished

Captain Webb reports that there has been daily skirmishing between our forces and the enemy near Yorktown, and that on Wednesday there was more firing than previously, and there was much more appearance of an engagement than there had been.
The movement to cross Warwick river was no doubt with the view of flanking our line of defence; but this stratagem had no doubt attracted the notice of our army.

div3.head: The Virginia.
div3.p: It was last night currently reported that the President had received a dispatch from Norfolk that the Virginia had yesterday successfully encountered a number of the enemy's transports in Hampton Roads, and that she had destroyed several of them We were not able to trace the report to any authentic source up to 11 o'clock, but we incline to the opinion that there may be some foundation for it. At the time of writing, the press has received no information on the subject.

div3.head: From the Valley.
div3.p:
A gentleman who made his escape from the lower Valley within the last few days gives us some important information from that section.
He confirms all that we have heretofore published of the inducements held out by the enemy to the negroes to desert their rightful owners.
He states that Col Geary, of Kansas notoriety, in a conversation with a citizen of Clarke county, told him that he did not mean to disguise or conceal the fact that they intended the staves should be liberated, and that he wished it distinctly understood that every negro in Clarke county was as free as his master.
This the negroes seem to perfectly understand, and were taking advantage of it, hundreds of them quitting their comfortable homes to snuff the breeze of an adulterated freedom in the North.
Not content with leaving themselves, many of them were stealing horses and riding off under the protection of the Federal authorities.

In reference to the battle at Kernstown, the gentleman alluded to thinks that the enemy's loss in killed alone must have been near one thousand.
The result of the fight was not regarded as a victory by the enemy, the greatest confusion existing among them in Winchester the night after its occurrence, and preparations were made to evacuate the place in the event of Gen. Jackson's advance.
Our informant states that Gen. Shields has recently been reinforced, and has now under him about twenty-five thousand men.

div3.head: The gunboat fund.
div3.p:
The following letter enclosed the sum of $200, which has been handed over to Mr. Maury, who has charge of the gunboat fund so patriotically begun by the ladies.
We publish the letter of the patriotic contributor, who appeals justly and with proper emphasis to his fellow-countrymen, and especially the men of means, to aid in the important enterprise:

opener.salute: To the Editors of the Dispatch:

div4.p:
It affords pleasure to see an occasional response to the fund to build the gunboat Richmond Enclosed find check for two hundred dollars; place it in proper hands.
We need many such boats as the one contemplated.--There is no telling the disasters that will befall us in the delay of their construction.--Why so much apathy among your princely merchants and elsewhere?
Be not deceived — this contest cannot be carried on without individual sacrifices, and whilst so many can command thousands upon thousands to speculate in sugar, tobacco, cotton, bacon, and salt, do they flatter themselves that others will spend and be spent to protect their property?
Again, I say, let them not be deceived.
Unless all come up speedily to the work, their property is in danger of being lost, and worse than lost, in the hands of an oppressive tyrant, who is doing all in his power to overrun the land.
Delay is indeed dangerous — imminently perlites.
We have just raised two volunteer companies in Sullivan county under the last call, and armed them at our expense with Mississippi rifles.

div3.head: Attack on Fort Pulaski.
div3.p:
Savannah, April 10--There is heavy firing in the direction of Fort Pulaski this morning.
The flight of the shells is plainly visible from the city.

div4.head: [Second dispatch]
div4.p:
Savannah, April 10.--Five of the enemy's batteries commenced the attack on Fort Pulaski at 6 o'clock this morning the Fort replies slowly, but deliberately.
The enemy's shells appear to buret come distance over the Fort.
No apprehensions are footsore in regard to the Fort.
The bombardment continues heavy.

div4.head: [Third Dispatch]
div4.p:
--P. M — The bombardment continued with unabated fury until night, but ceased wholly about 7½ 'clock.
No information of the result has been received, except that the flag-staff of the fort was shot off, all communication being cut off. A messenger, via underground railroad, for looked for to-night.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
A young gentleman, (British subject,) who is exempt from military duty, is desire of getting some Employment; is comepetent in any branch of counting-house work and would be willing to make himself generally useful.
Address "J. W. M.," Dispatch officer.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--to Hire,
At Chimborezo Hospital, fifty young
Negro men,
to nurse the sick.
Apply immediately, to Dr. J. B. hc. Aw at the Hospital, at 11 o'clock A. M. or-to Wm. K. Smith Steward of No. 3

div3.head: Ranaway--$200 reward
div3.p:
--From the residence of the subscriber, on the 30th Nov., Negro Boy Isaac, about 30 years old, 5½ feet high, ginger-bread complexion, of pleasant and polite manners, hair short and happy, and is left handed.
I will give the above reward for the apprehension and delivery of said boy in the jail at Orange C. H.

This negro ran off in consequence of having committed a most brutal and unprovoked murder upon the person of my overseer, and it behooves the community at large to be on the look out for this The may be in the vicinity of Vrederlakaburg
div3.closer:
Louisa C Taliaferro
Rapid Ann P. O. Culpeper county, Va. de 12--d3t&codts

div3.head: Pipe Stems, Pipe Stems.
div3.p: --A large loss of Root Pipe Steams, for sale at low prices, by
div3.closer:
R. W. Powers, Druggist,
Corner Main and 15th sts.

div3.p:
Quotations have undergone very slight alteration since our last.
Business is still exceedingly limited.
The great consumer, the Government, buys, through his agents at many points and throughout the country.
The trade here is much restricted to the locality.
There is a demand for goods for country dealer, but stocks are so low that they can not be supplied but partially.

Stocks are moving up and down most singularly.
There is a sudden heavy demand for North Carolina bonds, and they have gone up considerably above par. Confederate and Virginia are, without apparent reason, lower.
The insurance stocks have all dropped in value.
Bread — Navy, 4 cents; Pilot, 5 cents; Butter and Soda, 8 cents per 18.
Bacon — Stock light and firm at 26 to 27 for hog round; Hams, 26a28 cents per lb.
Butter — The Provost Marshal has fixed the maximum of retail prices at 50c, to take affect Monday.
Corn — We quote 85 cents per bushel.
Corn meal--$1al 05 per bushel.
Coffee — Rio, 70 cents per lb.; supply nearly exhausted.

Candles — Adamantine, 75a80 cents; Tallow, 23a25 cents.
$7.50; Family $8a$8 50; all by the dray load.
Cement — James River, $2.50a3.00 per bbl.
Cotton — 94a10 cents per lb.
Cotton Yarns--None. Candlewick, 50 cents per lb.
Dried Fruit--Peaches, unpeeled, from $2.25 to 2.50; Pealed, $5.00a6.50; Apples, $1.60a$1 75 per bushel.
Forage — Timothy, $1.99a$2.00; Clover, $1.80a$1.85; Sheaf Cats, $1.75a$1 85; Shucks, $1a1.25 per cwt.

Fertilizers — James River Manipulation guano, $60 per ton; stock small and rapidly reducing.
Mexican guano, $25; Sombrero, $35; Bone Ash, $40. Little of nothing doing in Fertilizes
Feather — Quiet, at 37½ a 40 cents per lb.
Flaxseed — Nominal; $1,50.
Flour — We quote Superfine at $7a$7 25; Extra $7.50a$7 75; Family $8.50a$9.
Hides — Green, 6 cents; salted, 9½ cents; dry, 12a 15 cents.
iron--English refined and American, but a small supply, which is sold in limited quantities at 8 cents per lb.; Swedes, none in market.
Leather — Sole, 80a85 cts.per lb; Upper $1 per lb.; Harness 75a80 cents; Rough Skirting 55a65 cts.; Calf Skins $48a55 per dozen.--Stock of all kinds very light.
Lard — 21a23 cents.
Lime — Mountain unslacked, $2.00 to $2.50 per bbl.; according to quantity.
Molasses — New Orleans, $1.30 to 1.40 cts.
Nails — Old Dominion, 10a11 cents.
Offal (mill)--Bran, 30 cents; shorts, 35 cents. Brownstuffs, 40 cents; shipstuffs, 70 cents.
Oil — Tanners', $1.12a1.50; machine, $1.50a$2 per gallon.
Oats — We quote 80 cents per bushel.
Rye--$1.50a$2.00 per bushel
Seed — Clover Seed, $12a$14--latter by retail; Timothy, $5½a$6½
Soda — Best English, 40 cents per lb.

Sugars — Brown, 24a26 cents per lb.; coffee, 27a28 cents.
All qualities firm.
Salt — Some sales of North Carolina Salt at $11 per stock of 100 lbs:

Tobacco — The breaks of Tobacco are small, and most of the tobacco offered at this time is re-opened.
There is not so much animation in the market, and prices are lower.
We quote inferior Lucas at $2½a$2¾ good $3a$3¾ inferior leaf $5a$5½; good $6½ 7 ½; fine $8a$9½a$10.
Tallow — 15a16 cents per lb.

Wheat — Red $1 10a1 20; white $1.15 a 1.25, and dull.
Few buyers at these prices.
Wool — Market firm, and arrivals light 90 a 95 cents per pound.

div4.head: Cattle market.
div4.p: Beef — We quote at $6.00a8.00 gross, which is 12 to 16 net.

Sheep — Supply light.
Extra quality, $8 to $9 gross.
Hogs — In demand at $15 to $16 net.

div4.head: Money matters.
div4.p:
Specie — We quote gold and silver at 60 to 75 per cent. premium.
Very little doing.
Bank notes — Nearly all Southern Bank notes are taken on deposit by our Banks.--We note the following as rejected for the want of arrangement to make them current at Bank:

Georgia--City Bank, Augusta; Mechanics' Bank, do; Bank of Augusta; Augusta insurance and Banking Company; all 1 per cent. discount; and Bank of the Empire State, Rome, Ga., and Northwestern Bank, Ringgold, Ga., 2 per cent. discount.

North Carolina--Bank of Lexington; Bank of Clarendon; Bank of Commerce, Newbern.
Bank of Fayetteville, and Bank of Washington, all 1 per cent. discount.

On Thursday, the 27th ult. at Her father's residence, by the Rev. William D Thomas, the bride's brother.
Dr. Wm. D. Quensunberry, of Carolina county, to Mary Milla, daughter of Jon Them as, Jr., of Richmond.

At his residence, on Union Hill, on Wednesday, the 9th April at 4 ½ o'clock P. M. in to 48th year of his age, John leaving a wife and four children.
His funeral will take place from his late residence, on 27th street, beyond Venable, this evening, at 4½ o'clock.
At Jamestown Island, on Tuesday, 8th inst., of typhoid pneumonia, Chas. E. Wood, only son of Chas. Wood, deceased, aged 28 years.

He was a member of Capt. Jos. W. Barlows company.
He leaves a mother and three sisters to mouth their loss.
The funeral will take place from St. Peter's Cathedral, this evening, at 5½ o'clock, to which its friends and acquaintances are invited without further notice.
Yesterday morning, 10th inst., at 3 o'clock Olivia, wife of Paul Bargamin, and daughter of Mrs. Sallie M and the late John Parrar, of Henrico.
The friends of the family, and of Mrs Parrar, are requested to attend the funeral from the First Baptist (Dr. Barrowst) Church this morning at 11 o'clock.
In this city on the 10th instant, Charles Breckinridge Dawson, son of P. S. and Henrietta M Dawson, aged 3 years and 8 days.
He will be buried at 3 o'clock, this afternoon.
At Rock Spring, in Richmond county, Va, April 1st Alexander Appley, infant of Fanny S and R. Alexander Be field, aged two months and 27 days.

div3.head:
Explanation of the law
for Revising Virginia's quota.
div3.p: Resolved, by the General Assembly, That the true intent and meaning of the on the 10th day of February, 1862, providing for raising Virginia's quota of the Confederate Army, makes it the duty of the Governor to fill up companies now in service to a minimum of one hundred man, to be supplied by voluntary enlistment or draft; that until the companies now in service have been so filled, the organization of new companies is in contravention of the policy adopted by the General Assembly in the act afore said.

That the Governor, therefore, be and he is hereby requested not to accept any new companies until these already in service have been up as the law directs, unless hereafter specially authorized so to do.
div3.closer:
A copy from the Roliz — Tette:
Wm. H. Gordon, Jr.,
C. H. D. and K. of R.
[Passed March 3d. 1862.] mh 1--cw4w

div3.head: Ranaway.--$50 reward
div3.p:
--Ranaway, from my farm in Henrico co., on the night of the 21d inst., four negro men, to wit: Isham Abram, Jack and Pleasants.
Isham is an old man, about 55 years old; when spoken to looked down — Abram is a tall, brown mulatto, aged 25 years--Jack is 45 years old, and has one every much swollen — Pleasants, aged 20 years, stammers when spoken to I will give the above reward for the delivery of said negroes or secured in any jail so I can get them, or $1250 for each.

div3.head: By the Governor of Virginia — a Proclamation.
div3.p:
--Whereas, a vacancy has occurred in the House of Representative of the Congress of the Confederate States, by the resignation of Roger A. Pryor, the member elected from the District composed of the city of Petersburg and the counties of Dinwiddie.
Cheater field, Powhatan, America, Nottoway, Cumberland Goochland, and Prince George; Therefore, F. John Letcher, Governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia, do hereby require the Sergeant of the city and Sheriffs of the counties aforesaid to hold an election at the several places of voting prescribed by law in the said city and counties, on the 24th day or the present month, (April,) for a member of Congress to till the vacancy a ore
Given under my hand as Governor, and under the seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this 7th day of April, 1862, and in the year of the Commonwealth the eighty-sixth
div3.closer:
John Letcher.
By the Governor:
George W. Munford,
Secretary of the Common wealth.
Petersburg papers please copy. ah 10--swd

div3.head: By the Governor of Virginia a Proclamation.
div3.p: --Information having been received by the Executive that Robert Goodson, who was confined in the jail of the county of Franklin, under a charge of grand larceny, is now going at large; Therefore, I do hereby offer a reward of one hundred dollars to any person or persons who shall arrest the said Robert Goodson and deliver him into the jail of said county; and i do moreover require all officers of this Commonwealth, civil and military, and request the people generally, to use their best exertions to procure the arrest of the said Goodson, that he may be brought to justice
Given under my hand as Governor, and under the Less Seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this 9th day of April, in the year 1862.
div3.closer:
John Leicher.
By the Governor:
George W. Munford.
Secretary of the Commonwealth.
Robert Goodson is about 45 years old, about 6 feet 2 inches high, of rawboned, muscular frame, dark, swarthy complexion, black eyes, hair, and beard and slight stoop in the shoulders ap 10 --sws

div3.p: States deals with slavery as a fact, and gives it, as such, certain rights"

Such, then, is a very brief but accurate outline of the extraordinary argument of Wou Phillips in favor of the legality of slavery by the common law of England, by the common law and charters of all the recognized by the articles of Confederation, expressly protected by the Constitution of the United States, and not in the slightest degree by the Declaration of Independence!

Headq'rs of Henrico,
Richmond Va.,April 9th, 1861.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 13.

1 Paragraphs 1 and 2, General Orders No. 12 Headquarters Department of Henrico, March 31st, 1862, are not confined in their operation to venders of produce in the mar but apply to Grocers, Commission Merchants, and every character of in pro within the city and the surrounding ten miles of country under martial law. All of provisions must conform to the Tariff of Prices prescribed by paragraph 11.
of General Orders, No. 12, and where not adhered to, both buyer and seller will suffer such punishment as may be imposed by a court martial, and the produce sold will be for to the informer, who, if interested in the sale, is exempted from punishment.

div3.head: Battalion of Cavalry.
div3.p:
--In the month of February I received authority from the Secretary of War to raise a Battalion or Regiment of Cavalry.
I have hesitated to under take to do so until this time, and I now propose to raise a Battalion of Cavalry.

Persons desiring to unite with me in this patriotic effort, and those wishing authority to recruit and raise companies, will address me at this place, or what is still better, report in person at once.
I expect to have two companies of infantry and one of artillery attached to my command.
Call at the office of the Battalion, Main street, Richmond, Va., opposite the office of the Southern Express Company.

Office,

Pates' Battalion.
div3.p: We, the undersigned, are authorized by Capt Henry C. Pate, to recruit A Company of Cavalry, consisting of 60 men, to be mustered is to the service of the C. S. A. for 3 years of during the war. Members coming this company are entitled to the bounty of $50 and $12 per month pay.

Horses, equipments, and subsistence, furnished each recruit.
Those who furnish their own horses, will be entitled to $25 per month.
Office on Main and near the corner of 9th street, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Infantry Company.
div3.p:
The undersigned being authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a company of Light Infantry for the war, and having united with Mr. Charles H. Exall. and Mr. Wm.
J. and G. W. Jones in the enterprise, has opened a Recruiting Office on the West side of 10th street, between Main and Bans. Men enlisting in this company will receive the usual bounty, &c.
This company will form a part of the battalion of infantry being raised by R. G. Scott, Jr., Esq., who may be found at the same office.

div3.p:
A few more Recruits wanted for Courtney's Artillery, now stationed at Rappahannock river.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid.
Apply at the Franklin House, on 6th, between Broad and Marshall streets, to

div3.head:
War Department,
Adj't and Insp, General's Office,
Richmond April 8th, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 21.
1. The following Proclamation is published in the information of all corned:
Proclamation:
By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus:

I Jefferson Davis President of the Confederate States of America do proclaim that martial law is hereby extended over the Department of East Tennessee under the command of Major-General E. K. Smith; and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction., (with the exception of that enabling the Courts to take cognizance of the predate of wills, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, the qualification of guardians, to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property to make orders concerning roads and bridged, to cross county levies, and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus in the Department aforesaid.
In faith whereof I have hereunto Signed my name and set my seal this 8th day of April, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.
[Signed] Jefferson Davis."

II. Major General E. K. Smith commanding Department of East Tennessee is charged with the one execution of the foregoing Proclamation.--He will forthwith establish an efficient military police and will enforce the following orders: All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited and the distilleries will forthwith be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed.

III.
All persons infringing the above prohibition, will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a court martial, provided that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a Regimental Court Martial, as directed by the 67th Article of War.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
[Signed] S. Cooper.
Adj't and Inspector General. ap 8--6t

div3.p: the following named men have deserted from the station and the Government reward will be paid for their apprehension:

div3.head:
Heavy Artillery.
$50 bounty, and Uniforms furnished.
div3.p:
The undersigned are authorized by the secretary of War to raise a Company for the heavy Artillery service.
We have been for the past eleven months in active service as Lieutenants of such a company, and have already a number of men enlisted.
All who desire to join us will please apply at our recruiting office, No. 17, Main street, upstairs, to Wm. Lawson, Company H, First Regiment Virginia Volunteers; or at our Camp in Yorktown.
Attention, Volunteers
Battery secured.

The assigned, having secured a splendid Battery of field-pieces, have authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, to be mustered in the Provisional Army of Virginia for the war, and have received authority from the Governor to recruit volunteers from the Militia.
to fill the ranks of the Crutchfield Light Artillery.
The company will be, mustered in as soon as a sufficient number of volunteers have been received.
A fine opportunity now presents itself to those who do not wish to go as militiamen, to enroll themselves as volunteers.
No substitutes received.
Apply at the office of the Old Dominion Insurance Company, under the St Charles Hotel.

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--I am authorized by the Governor to receive Substitutes to my company of Light Artillery, and to muster them in as they come.
Those, therefore, who desire to procure substitutes, or who wish to become substitutes, should call at once at my headquarters, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.

Adjt' and Insp'r Gen's Office,
Richmond April 8, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders no 80.
[extract]

XVIII.
On the discharge of troops leaving the service the commanders of regiments and battalions will take away all arms of every description, whether public or private — private arms to be paid for by the Ordnance officer, or receipts given which will entitle holders to payment.

Jno. Withers. A. A. G. ap 9--1w

div3.head: Attention, Teamsters.
div3.p:
--I wish to enlist ten good Drivers for my Battery.
To experienced men. I will give $50 each in addition to the Government bounty of $50.
Volunteers now in service but whose term of enlistment will expire during this month, will be received upon application to the undersigned by letter, at Camp Lee, near Richmond.

div3.head:
Headq'r Dickinson's Battery,
Camp Lee, April 8, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders.--Members of this company who are not present by next Wednesday will be advertised as deserters, and treated accordingly.

Furloughs and passes given are hereby revoked.
Members reporting themselves must come prepared for service.
The bounty will be paid immediately on the formation of the regiment
Wanted--Twenty good and reliable Sen to complete a battery of six pieces, already obtained.

div3.head: Wise Zouaves.
div3.p:
The undersigned is enlisting a company of infantry for the 20th Regiment Virginia Volunteers, to be called the Wise Zouaves, in compliment of the memory of the late Captain Wise.
This company will be instructed by Mr. C. F. Pardigon in the Zouave drill of the French infantry, and taught by him the bayonet exercise.
Being familiar in all its detail, and having sided Captain Car in the translation of the French works on Bayonet Exercise, his ability to instruct in that drill cannot be questioned.

Militiamen desiring to enter this service will apply to the undersigned, on 12th street, one door above Main.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid the men when mustered into the Confederate service.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't. Of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., March 11, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 6.

II.
Railroad companies are forbidden to transport into this city or out of it, spirituous liquors or other intoxicating beverages.

III.
Superintendents of railroads are requested to report daily to the Provost Marshal the number of passengers passing over their roads out of the city of Richmond.
div3.closer:
By order of
Brig. Gen'l Jno. H. Winder, Com. &c.
L. R. Page. A. A. Gen'l. mh 13--ts

div3.head: Bogge's Battalion of Light Artillery.
div3.p: --As all difficulty about obtaining guns for this command has been removed, I desire to organize my Battalion within the next ten days.

The Commandants of Companies that I have accepted will report to me immediately, and hold themselves subject to an order to rendezvous their command.
at such a time and place as I shall indicate.
I wish to secure immediately one good company, composed of new recruits.
Any persons desirous of joining this Battalion, can report to me, or to any of the Captains of my command.

Capt. S. T. Martin, of this city, and Capt. T. C Leake, of Henrico, are receiving recruits to complete their commands.
I recommend them with confidence, as gentlemen and competent officers.
The former may be found on Bank two doors above 12th; the latter at the corner of Broad st. and Brook Avenue.
I have been authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Regiment of heavy Artillery for three years or the war.

This regiment is rapidly filling up, and wants only a few companies requisite to its complete on. I should be glad to confer with contains who have companies, and also with those who desire to raise companies.

"Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years, or the war, will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are sworn into service and accepted, upon inspection by a medical officer, together with transportation and subsistence from the time and place of enlistment, until inspects and mustered."

Twelve months men can re-enlist singly or by companies for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty; and will also be transferred during the twenty days previous to the expiration of their present term.
Volunteers will be received singly or by companies from any portion of the Confederacy.
Office--Tenth street, three doors from Main City Post-Office, Box 877.

div3.head:
Headquarters Ordnance Departm't,
Richmond, Va.,March 28th, 1862.
div3.p:
This Department is Desirous of purchasing arms from those parties having good double-barrel shot guns, sporting rifles, or any kind of weapons that will be useful in the field.
These arms will be fairly appraised on their delivery in Richmond, and payments will be promptly made
Agents heretofore collecting State arms for this Department are requested to collect and forward these private arms as promptly as possible.
div3.closer:
Dimmock,
Col. of Ordnance of Virginia.
Whig and Enquires copy. mh 29--tf

div3.p: The undersigned has been authorized to organize a Battalion of Infantry, to form part of the Maryland Line.

Under an act of Congress, approved February 15, 1862 any native or adopted citizen of Maryland may, upon his own application, be transferred at once to the Maryland Line.
Or any company composed of citizens of Maryland or the District of Columbia may upon application, be so transferred.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining this Battalion, will apply in person at the office of Weston & Williams, No. 15 Pearl street, or by mail to

Richmond. Va. mh 18--ts

Rifle guns,

allowed to each recruit, and

div3.p:

at once.

div3.head:

Crescent Zouaves Battalion.
div3.p:
Wanted--Recruits to fill up the battalion of Crescent Zouaves, under the command of Major W Byllested.

A near uniform of gray cloth, Zouave style, will be furnished.

This corps will be one of the best organized and equipped in the service, and its commander having had many years' military experience, both in this and foreign countries, will make it a battalion worthy of the admiration of his commanding General, and one that young men will be proud to serve in. Those wishing to enlist will apply to
div3.closer:

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on Union Hill, on Friday night last, a negro Woman named Daphne.
The above reward will be paid for her apprehension and delivery to Mr. A. Richards, Franklin street

Daphne is about 30 years old, tall, black, with a very prominent forehead, and is sprightly looking and intelligent.
She is probably concealed somewhere in the city, as she has a sister and numerous friends living here.

div3.head: Ten dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the arrest of a Servant Woman named Dolly.
Said Woman is above the medium height; quite dark, and quick spoken.
Dolly was hired from Miss Merrian, on Church Hill, and is supposed to be lurking about Church or Union Hill, or Shedtown.
The above reward will be paid for her delivery to me, at Chiles & Chenery's, or if lodged in Lumpkin's Jail.

div3.head: $50 and ten dollars reward for a Runaway,
div3.p:
--Ten dollars reward will be paid for the delivery to jail or to me, of a mulatto Girl, named Emma.
Said Girl is about 5 feet 2 inches high, and rather spare-build, small face, and tolerably straight hair.

I will also give $50 to any one who can give good proof who has been harboring her Stewards of hospitals are particularly requested to look out for her, and to inform me it caught, as the Girl falsely pretends to be a free woman
div3.closer:
James Abel,
opposite Fish Market. ap 8--6t* 17th st.,

div3.head: $25 reward
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my store, on Tuesday morning, 15th instant, my negro Boy, Lewis Washington.
He is a bright mulatto, thick set, about 5 feet high, 15 years old; had on when last seen a brown sack coat, brown pants, and a military cap. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me.
div3.closer:
S. S. Cottrell,
No. 129 Main street. ap 2--ts
